Here are some suggestions on how to build better trumpet practice habits:

1. start small: when building good habits, it helps to start small. establish a moderately comfortable practice routine that you can easily follow, and then gradually increase the duration, volume, or difficulty gradually. building habits takes time, and it is important not to feel too overwhelmed or take on too much too soon. 2. create an environment that supports learning: create an environment that supports learning by identifying the distractions that most frequently derail your practice sessions, and do what you can to eliminate them. designated practice space that you avoid other activity from, setting a regular routine, and having the necessary supplies readily available to support your practice can make building habits easier. 3. visualize and plan out your routine: visualize your daily practice routine and break down your goals into small actionable tasks. planning your practice session ahead helps you focus on the work that needs to be done and provides you with a sense of accomplishment when you complete each task. 4. stay accountable: stay accountable to someone who can hold you accountable for your practice habits. this may be a teacher or a practice partner who can check in with you to ensure that you are staying on track. 5. reward yourself: celebrating one's achievements is a potent tool for minimizing our brains' resistance to new habits. reward yourself when you make progress through practice, such as treating yourself to a favorite meal or activity. remember, building habits takes time, effort, and persistence. establish a routine and stick to it, and before you know it, practicing the trumpet will be just another part of your daily routine.
